data.title: Genealogy of the Royal Family of the Two Sicilies
data.text:
Genealogy of the Royal Family of the Two Sicilies1

House Bourbon

HM Ferdinando IV Antonio Pasquale Giovanni Nepomuceno Serafin Januario Benito King of Naples and Sicily, Infante of Spain

(Since December 8th, 1816:) HM Ferdinando I Antonio Pasquale Giovanni Nepomuceno Serafin Januario Benito King of the Two Sicilies, Infante of Spain

(Born as: HRH Don Fernando Antonio Pascual Juan Nepomuceno Serafin Januario Benito Infante of Spain

* Naples, January 18th, 1751

 Naples, January 4th, 1825

King of Naples and Sicily, October 6th, 1759; King of the Two Sicilies, December 8th, 1816

Married:

(by proxy) Vienna, April 7th and (in person) Caserta, May 12th, 1768:

HI & RH Marie Caroline Luise Josephe Johanna Antonie Princess Imperial and Archduchess of Austria, Princess Royal of Hungary and Bohemia, Princess of Tuscany

* Schlo� Sch�nbrunn, Vienna, August 13th, 1752

 Schlo� Hetzendorf near Vienna, September 8th, 1814

(morganatically) Palermo, November 27th, 1814:

Donna Lucia Migliaccio Duchess di Floridia

* Syracuse, July 19th, 1770

 Naples, April 26th, 1826

Children from the first marriage:

HRH Maria Teresa Carolina Giuseppina Princess of Naples and Sicily

* Naples, June 6th, 1772

 (in childbirth) Vienna, April 13th, 1807

Married:

(by proxy) Naples, August 15th and (in person) Hofpfarrkirche des Heiligen Augustinus, Vienna, September 19th, 1790:

HIM Franz Joseph Karl Emperor of Austria, King of Hungary and Bohemia

(Born as: HI & RH Franz Joseph Karl Prince Imperial and Archduke of Austria, Prince Royal of Hungary and Bohemia, Prince of Tuscany)

(Since March 1st, 1792:) HIM Franz II Joseph Karl Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire, King in Germany, of Jerusalem, Hungary and Bohemia, Archduke of Austria

(Since August 11th, 1804:) HIM Franz II Joseph Karl Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire, Emperor of Austria, King in Germany, of Jerusalem, Hungary and Bohemia

* Florence, February 12th, 1768

 Vienna, March 2nd, 1835

Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire, King of Hungary and Bohemia, Archduke of Austria, Duke of Milan, March 1st, 1792 (deposed as Duke of Milan: May 9th, 1796; abdicated as Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire: August 6th, 1806); Grand Duke of Cracow, October 24th, 1795; Duke of Friaul, Lord of Cattaro, 1797; Emperor of Austria, August 11th, 1804; Duke of Milan, April 28th, 1814 - April 7th, 1815; King of Lombardia-Venice, April 7th, 1815; King of Illyria, Duke of Salzburg, Duke of Ragusa and Zara, Prince of Triente and Brixen, June 10th, 1815

HRH Luisa Maria Amelia Teresa Princess of Naples and Sicily

* Naples, July 27th, 1773

 Vienna, September 19th, 1802

Married:

(by proxy) Naples, August 15th and (in person) Vienna, September 19th, 1790:

HI & RH Ferdinando III Giuseppe Giovanni Battista Grand Duke of Tuscany, Prince Imperial and Archduke of Austria, Prince Royal of Hungary and Bohemia

(Born as:) HI & RH Ferdinand Joseph Johann Baptist Prince Imperial and Archduke of Austria, Prince Royal of Hungary and Bohemia, Prince of Tuscany

* Florence, May 6th, 1769

 Florence, June 18th, 1824

Grand Duke of Tuscany, July 22nd, 1790 (driven out by the French in 1799 and dispossessed by the Treaty of Lun�ville in 1801; restored to the throne: May 30th, 1814)

Created Duke and Elector of Salzburg, December 26th, 1802 (exchanged Salzburg for W�rzburg: December 25th, 1805); Elector of W�rzburg, December 25th, 1805; Grand Duke of W�rzburg, 1806 (renounced when he was restored to the Grand Duchy of Tuscany: May 30th, 1814)

HRH Carlo Francesco Giuseppe Gennaro, Prince of Naples and Sicily, Duke di Calabria

 Naples, December 17th, 1778

Footnotes:

With special thanks to Hein Bruins, Brigitte Gastel Lloyd, Netty Leistra, Clara Rodr�guez �lvarez and Paul Theroff.

Within the Royal Family of the Two Sicilies there is a great dispute whether or not this renouncation is valid. Prince Carlo's descendants argue that the renunciation clearly applied only in the case that Prince Carlo or his descendants should succeed to the Spanish throne. Various interpretations have been made of the acts and statutes involved, and the dispute seems to be without a definitive resolution. Therefore there is a great dispute about the question who is the Head of the Family. If the renunciation is valid, the Head of the Family is HRH Prince Ferdinand Duke di Castro. If the renouncation is not valid, the Head of the Family is HRH Prince Carlos Duke di Calabria.
